title: I do not track you
text:
In times where businesses are built upon data collection, I am exploring how my designs can better account for human values.
So I chose to avoid data collection: this website does not have analytics, third-party web fonts or social network buttons that track you. No cookies, no cookie banner either.
The ‚ÄúI do not track you‚Äù declaration is inspired by Laura Kalbag.

title: Green Kolding
text:
TLDR 







As a local youth organization that aims to push climate and sustainability action, Green Kolding struggles to attract participants. Another problem is its members‚Äô uncertainty about what Green Kolding stands for.



I conceptualized and conducted a co-design workshop to explore and define Green Kolding‚Äôs identity. We then interviewed the two heads of the organization. Analyzing the data with empathy mapping identified the need for a website which communicates Green Kolding‚Äôs identity and attracts new members. We developed a website prototype and conducted user experience tests with the target group.



The workshop‚Äôs goal was to define Green Kolding‚Äôs identity but this was difficult because the number of attendants who regularly engage with Green Kolding was very low. Despite this, our interviews led to a deeper understanding of the organization‚Äôs self-perception and needs. We addressed those needs with a website prototype but testing it revealed that Green Kolding‚Äôs identity remains vague and discourages potential members from joining.

title: Designing to support user agency
text:
TLDR 







In today‚Äôs attention economy, digital interfaces undermine self-control. This results in detrimental effects on user‚Äôs well-being. I therefore explored how we can design interfaces that give back control (i.e.¬†user agency) toward the people who interact with these interfaces. 



Following a design thinking approach, I used desk research, probe studies and affinity mapping to explore how design mechanisms on Instagram support and undermine user control. Through experience prototyping, I then developed alternative design patterns that support sense of agency.



I identified six design patterns that describe how design mechanisms on Instagram support and undermine user control. I further developed 4 prototypes that redesign Instagram‚Äôs design mechanisms for greater user agency.

title: Designing to support user agency
section: Relevance: Capturing attention at all costs
text:
Relevance: Capturing attention at all costs
Information technology is tightly woven through our contemporary lives, offering broad access to communication, knowledge, and entertainment. However, this wealth of information has made attention a scarce and therefore precious resource. This has resulted in a competition in which a very small number of exeptionally powerful organizations are continuously vying for people‚Äôs attention. Their technologies and products present ubiquitous temptations that frequently clash with other important activities in our lives. 


Moreover, information and communication technologies (ICT) are designed in a way that makes them exceptionally hard to resist: While people‚Äôs failure rate is 31% for smoking and 28% for drinking alcohol, they fail to resist media use 78% of the time (see figure). This is because design mechanisms such as push notifications and autoplay create task interruptions and task-irrelevant thoughts that put an additional strain on the self-control capacity of media users.  This loss of agency that users experience over their technology use comes with detrimental effects on their well-being. Short-term effects such as feelings of fruststration and guilt often translate to more long-term decreases in cognitive well-being, including behavioral addiction and reduced life satisfaction. I therefore asked:

How can we design interfaces that give back control (i.e., user agency) toward the people who interact with these interfaces?






‚Æ§ Media use shows the highest self-control failure rate of all 14 types of temptations. 1

title: Designing to support user agency
section: Research study design: moving from exploration to ideation
text:
Research study design: moving from exploration to ideation
To answer this question, my research study design followed a design thinking process (see figure). I also used IDEO‚Äôs method cards to come up with suitable methods for the different phases of my research. Regarding the Discover phase, for example, I gleaned inspiration from the following three IDEO method cards: Secondary research, Try it yourself, and Cultural probes.



‚Æ§ IDEO method cards that were selected in different phases of the research process, mapped on the Double Diamond design process model.


Analogue to the first Diamond of the design thinking process, I dedicated the first part of my research to exploring and understanding the problem. My research question was:

RQI: What existing design mechanisms in the Instagram mobile app influence sense of agency?

The inquiries in this phase included desk research, a probe study and its analysis through affinity diagramming. The results revealed distinct design features across Instagram‚Äôs design mechanisms that made participants feel less or more in control. I further identified 4 higher-level design patterns that describe how these design mechanisms undermine user sense of agency (see figure, visualized by four spherical shapes). These results informed my second research question:

RQII: What are alternative design mechanisms in the Instagram mobile app that might support sense of agency?

Analogue to the second Diamond of the design thinking process, the second part of my research process was concerned with finding solutions through ideating. For this, I developed four How might we (HMW) questions. Each question was based on one of the four design patterns for low agency. After generating a wide range of ideas, I chose to continue with one idea for each design challenge which resulted in a total of four experience prototypes. For potential inquries in the future (see figure, visualized by using lower contrast) I propose user testings to test whether the developed experience prototypes successfully support user sense of agency.



‚Æ§ Research study design

title: Designing to support user agency
section: Discover: From desk research to intervention
text:
Discover: From desk research to intervention
I began my project with desk research, exploring the following three research areas: dark patterns of interaction design, philosophy of technology and previous work on sense of agency for well-being. The results contributed an essential component of groundwork to my research as well as informed the further course of my research process. For example, there is a need for research to identify and examine design patterns that manipulate users into spending time and attention in an app against their best interests (so-called attention capture dark patterns). 2
I then designed and conducted my own intervention: a probe study with a total of 12 participants. My aim was to collect user experiences and form an empathic understanding of how existing design mechanisms in the Instagram mobile app influence user sense of agency. Each probe kit included 2 assignments and 2 corresponding diaries (see figure). The first assignment asked participants to name and explain things that made them feel least in control (LC) of how they spend their time on Instagram. Thereafter, the second assignment asked them to name and explain things that made them feel most in control (MC).



‚Æ§ A snapshot of the creation process of a diary (top-left), the cover of a final diary (top-right), and the first double page of a low control diary (bottom)


Besides the diary, each participant received a number of other materials (see figure). For example, the envelope for study day 1 contained straps to attach the diary to the back of a smartphone (see figure, A.2)



‚Æ§ The different materials included in one probe kit



Lesson learned
Probe studies are a lot of work, instructions must be well thought-through Besides the diary, each participant received a number of other materials (see figure). For example, the envelope for study day 1 contained straps to attach the diary to the back of a smartphone (see figure, A.2)

title: Designing to support user agency
section: Define: Bringing all the data together
text:
Define: Bringing all the data together
DEFINE: Affinity mapping



‚Æ§ Affinity notes created from the data gained from the probe studies





‚Æ§ A part of the finalized affinity diagram



PoV:

Instagram users need to be more in control over how they spend their time in the Instagram app because current design mechanisms undermine their sense of agency, thereby deteriorating user well-being. This happens in four ways: by imposing unwanted information on users, by showing highly personalized content, by creating fear of missing out, and by determining the ease of an interaction.

4 types of design patterns for least control
3 types of design patterns for most control




‚Æ§; Types of design patterns that classify design mechanisms that make people feel least in control over how they spend their time in the Instagram app. The description explains how a design pattern undermines user sense of agency. Design patterns are listed in the order of frequency of corresponding responses from the affinity diagram.


Lesson learned: Analyzing on your own is hard, first affinity diagram was crap

title: Designing to support user agency
section: Develop: Designing to support user agency
text:
Develop: Designing to support user agency
DEVELOP - 4 HMW questions / design challenges - 4 prototypes



‚Æ§ Mockups of the original design (left) and the redesign (right) of the Feed and Stories mechanisms.





‚Æ§ Mockups of the original design (left) and the redesign (right) of the Reels mechanism.


Setback: Ideating on your own is hard, (no time for testing)
My Master Thesis sheds light on the exploitative tactics with which online platforms and digital technologies systematically undermine user‚Äôs self control. This loss of agency that users experience over their technology use comes with detrimental effects on their well-being.
Based on these findings, I used experience prototyping to create 4 prototypes. These redesigs support user sense of agency
Taking one of most widespread social media platforms worldwide, my Master thesis explores and redesigns how design mechanisms influence user agency on Instagram.
such as push notifications and autoplay

title: About
section: I‚Äôm a designer with an analytic mindset ‚Ä¶
text:
I‚Äôm a designer with an analytic mindset ‚Ä¶
My main strength is my analytic mindset and my passion for research and complexity. I design to create understanding, spark compassion, and drive action. With my interdisciplinary background in human-computer interaction and branding, I call user studies and team collaboration the heart of my work approach.

title: About
text:
‚Ä¶ who recently began coding ‚Ä¶
I also enjoy talking to different stakeholders and presenting progress to clients. Sometimes I also code, like this website. Once I become fascinated by something, I can immerse myself fully in it (which is why I actually code a lot right now). You‚Äôll usually find me talking about ethics in design, initiatives and people that drive climate action, or great data visualization.

title: About
section: ‚Ä¶ and stops by a (skiing) trail as soon as she sees one.
text:
‚Ä¶ and stops by a (skiing) trail as soon as she sees one.
I enjoy fiddling around on a screen as much as taking some time off it. Like packing a tent and spending some days on a hike. The smell of roasted onions in the pan. Feeling the strain in my body during a run. Or playing countless rounds of Doppelkopf with friends (I grew up in Germany).

title: Website
text:
TLDR 







Green Kolding is a youth organization that aims to push climate and sustainability action in the municipality of Kolding, Denmark. Having started out with many early-attracted members shortly before the Covid-19 pandemic, the organization struggles to attract any participants at all ever since they started meeting again. Another problem is the member‚Äôs uncertainty about what Green Kolding stands for.



I conceptualized and conducted a co-design workshop with members and non-members to explore and define Green Kolding‚Äôs identity. We then interviewed the two heads of the organization. Analyzing the data with empathy mapping allowed us to identify the need for a website which communicates Green Kolding‚Äôs identity and attracts new members. We developed a website prototype and conducted user experience tests with the target group.



The workshop outcomes were limited to impulses for Green Kolding‚Äôs identity as participants who did not know Green Kolding prior to the workshop were numerically overrepresented and therfore overshadowed the opinions and perceptions of active members. Our interviews, on the other hand, revealed a deeper understanding of the organization‚Äôs self-perception and needs. Testing our website prototype revealed that the organization‚Äôs identity remains vague and discourages potential members from joining.

title: Portfolio
text:
Here‚Äôs what I do: my work ranges from projects in interdisciplanary teams, assignments during my time at the University of Southern Denmark, to my own fiddling-arounds in my spare time. I aim to describe each project as a whole, including its detours and setbacks. After all, failure is part of the design process! 
Apart from that, don‚Äôt hesitate to reach out if you want to know more about a specific project.
